layman:
SUBJECTIVE: The patient feels better today. Still having diarrhea and a lower appetite. Has been urinating well, about 600 mL since 7 a.m. No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  
GENERAL: Patient is not in distress, awake, alert, and knows name, location, and time.  
VITAL SIGNS: Blood pressure 102/64, heart rate 89, breathing 12 breaths per minute, temperature 96.8 °F, oxygen level 94 % on room air.  
HEENT (head, ears, eyes, nose, throat): Pupils equal, round, reactive to light and accommodation; eye movements normal.  
NECK: Flexible.  
CARDIOVASCULAR: Heart rhythm regular.  
RESPIRATORY: Lungs clear when listened to on both sides.  
ABDOMEN: Bowel sounds present, belly soft, no tenderness.  
EXTREMITIES: No swelling; pulses felt in all limbs.

LABORATORY DATA  
CBC: White blood cells 10.9 k/µL today (down from 17.3 k yesterday, 26.9 k when admitted). Hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL, hematocrit 31.3 %, platelets 370 k/µL.  
BMP: BUN 28.3 mg/dL (down from 32.2 mg/dL), creatinine 1.8 mg/dL (down from 1.89 mg/dL, 2.7 mg/dL on admission). Calcium 8.2 mg/dL. Sodium 139 mEq/L, potassium 3.9 mEq/L, chloride 108 mEq/L, CO₂ 22 mEq/L. Liver tests normal.  
Stool: Positive for Clostridium difficile.  
Blood culture: 131.  
O₂ saturation pending.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  
1. Likely improvement of Clostridium difficile colitis and urinary tract infection. Patient is stable, white blood cells are falling, and no fever.  
2. Acute kidney injury from dehydration; BUN and creatinine are improving.  
3. Continue Flagyl for C. difficile; Dr. X will evaluate in the morning.  
4. Continue Levaquin for urinary infection based on culture.  
5. White blood cells are improving.  
6. Small rise in heart enzymes on admission; follow up with cardiology.  
7. Possible pneumonia; continue vancomycin and Levaquin.  
8. Patient may be moved to telemetry monitoring.
